/home/hammer/slime/src/runtime/hash_util32.h

00001 /* Matthew Hammer <hammer@tti-c.org> */
00002 #if SLIME_HASH_BITS != 32
00003 #error "This shouldn't be included."
00004 #endif
00005 
00006 /*
00007   Note: These macros in this file were taken from Bob Jenkin's (public
00008   domain) C code:
00009 
00010   -- http://burtleburtle.net/bob/c/lookup3.c (32-bit)
00011 */
00012 
00013 #define rot(x,k) (((x)<<(k)) | ((x)>>(32-(k))))
00014 /*
00015 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00016 mix -- mix 3 32-bit values reversibly.
00017 
00018 This is reversible, so any information in (a,b,c) before mix() is
00019 still in (a,b,c) after mix().
00020 
00021 If four pairs of (a,b,c) inputs are run through mix(), or through
00022 mix() in reverse, there are at least 32 bits of the output that
00023 are sometimes the same for one pair and different for another pair.
00024 This was tested for:
00025 * pairs that differed by one bit, by two bits, in any combination
00026   of top bits of (a,b,c), or in any combination of bottom bits of
00027   (a,b,c).
00028 * "differ" is defined as +, -, ^, or ~^.  For + and -, I transformed
00029   the output delta to a Gray code (a^(a>>1)) so a string of 1's (as
00030   is commonly produced by subtraction) look like a single 1-bit
00031   difference.
00032 * the base values were pseudorandom, all zero but one bit set, or 
00033   all zero plus a counter that starts at zero.
00034 
00035 Some k values for my "a-=c; a^=rot(c,k); c+=b;" arrangement that
00036 satisfy this are
00037     4  6  8 16 19  4
00038     9 15  3 18 27 15
00039    14  9  3  7 17  3
00040 Well, "9 15 3 18 27 15" didn't quite get 32 bits diffing
00041 for "differ" defined as + with a one-bit base and a two-bit delta.  I
00042 used http://burtleburtle.net/bob/hash/avalanche.html to choose 
00043 the operations, constants, and arrangements of the variables.
00044 
00045 This does not achieve avalanche.  There are input bits of (a,b,c)
00046 that fail to affect some output bits of (a,b,c), especially of a.  The
00047 most thoroughly mixed value is c, but it doesn't really even achieve
00048 avalanche in c.
00049 
00050 This allows some parallelism.  Read-after-writes are good at doubling
00051 the number of bits affected, so the goal of mixing pulls in the opposite
00052 direction as the goal of parallelism.  I did what I could.  Rotates
00053 seem to cost as much as shifts on every machine I could lay my hands
00054 on, and rotates are much kinder to the top and bottom bits, so I used
00055 rotates.
00056 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00057 */
00058 #define mix(a,b,c) \
00059 { \
00060   a -= c;  a ^= rot(c, 4);  c += b; \
00061   b -= a;  b ^= rot(a, 6);  a += c; \
00062   c -= b;  c ^= rot(b, 8);  b += a; \
00063   a -= c;  a ^= rot(c,16);  c += b; \
00064   b -= a;  b ^= rot(a,19);  a += c; \
00065   c -= b;  c ^= rot(b, 4);  b += a; \
00066 }
00067 
00068 /*
00069 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00070 final -- final mixing of 3 32-bit values (a,b,c) into c
00071 
00072 Pairs of (a,b,c) values differing in only a few bits will usually
00073 produce values of c that look totally different.  This was tested for
00074 * pairs that differed by one bit, by two bits, in any combination
00075   of top bits of (a,b,c), or in any combination of bottom bits of
00076   (a,b,c).
00077 * "differ" is defined as +, -, ^, or ~^.  For + and -, I transformed
00078   the output delta to a Gray code (a^(a>>1)) so a string of 1's (as
00079   is commonly produced by subtraction) look like a single 1-bit
00080   difference.
00081 * the base values were pseudorandom, all zero but one bit set, or 
00082   all zero plus a counter that starts at zero.
00083 
00084 These constants passed:
00085  14 11 25 16 4 14 24
00086  12 14 25 16 4 14 24
00087 and these came close:
00088   4  8 15 26 3 22 24
00089  10  8 15 26 3 22 24
00090  11  8 15 26 3 22 24
00091 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00092 */
00093 #define final(a,b,c) \
00094 { \
00095   c ^= b; c -= rot(b,14); \
00096   a ^= c; a -= rot(c,11); \
00097   b ^= a; b -= rot(a,25); \
00098   c ^= b; c -= rot(b,16); \
00099   a ^= c; a -= rot(c,4);  \
00100   b ^= a; b -= rot(a,14); \
00101   c ^= b; c -= rot(b,24); \
00102 }
Generated on Thu Mar 5 14:27:55 2009 for CEAL by  1.5.6
